title: How Fifties women can boost their state pension payments – even with a five-year wait
text:
Women affected by the increase in state pension age lost their court battle last week and now face the prospect of retiring as much as six years later than planned. But it could still be possible for some Fifties women to boost their payouts.

The change – to increase the state pension age for women from 60 to 65, in line with men – was first announced in 1995 and Parliament later increased the minimum age further to 66 for both sexes. Younger people will not receive their state pension until age 67 or 68.

Women born in the Fifties argued that they were disproportionately affected by the changes and were not properly notified, giving them little time to prepare their finances to fill the unexpected...
description: Women affected by the increase in state pension age lost their court battle last week and now face the prospect of retiring as much as six years later than planned.
